supporting_text: The NAP emphasizes the One Health approach, addressing human, animal, and environmental health.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, such as preventing nosocomial infections and promoting appropriate antibiotic use.
The NAP outlines strategies for animal health, including improving husbandry conditions and promoting vaccination.
The NAP addresses the environmental release of antibiotics and antibiotic resistances, focusing on wastewater and soil.
The NAP includes actions related to the food chain and the role of agriculture in the emergence and spread of AMR.
The NAP mentions that an action plan will be published later, which will be regularly reviewed and used for reporting on implementation status.
The NAP states that measurable national-level AMR targets will be defined by the end of 2023.
The NAP includes the goal of reducing antibiotic use in veterinary medicine by 50% between 2018 and 2030.
The document does not specify any budget allocation for the strategies or actions.
The document does not include an assessment of future budget requirements.
The NAP mentions the Interministerial Working Group on Antimicrobial Resistance (IMAG AMR) for cross-ministerial coordination.
The NAP discusses the need for legal requirements and their enforcement to combat AMR.
The NAP emphasizes the importance of knowledge dissemination and training for medical professionals.
The NAP includes actions to improve public awareness about infections and appropriate antibiotic use.
The NAP highlights the importance of international cooperation and collaboration with organizations like WHO and FAO.
The NAP outlines the need for standardized surveillance and monitoring of antibiotic use and AMR.
The NAP discusses the need for improved surveillance systems to detect and report AMR.
The NAP includes prevention measures such as infection protection and control to reduce antibiotic use.
The NAP emphasizes the need to align with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP discusses the need for regulations on the use and dispensing of antibiotics.
The NAP includes measures to promote the rational use of antibiotics through legal frameworks.
The NAP highlights the importance of research and development for new antibiotics and diagnostic tools.
